Content: In paragraph 3 of Passage 1, which step of the experiment introduces the microbes in the flask?

A.Choice: filling two flasks with yeast water

B.Choice: heating the flasks to boiling

C.Choice: keeping one flask intact

D.Choice: breaking open one of the flasks

Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
In paragraph 5 of Passage 1, what is the 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗟𝗜𝗞𝗘𝗟𝗬 meaning of the word “illuminating”?

A.Choice: releasing into the air

B.Choice: making visible with light

C.Choice: activating by chemical reaction

D.Choice: pointing out through description

Content: Which choice provides the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: “were instead carried by dust in the air”

B.Choice: “The yeast water solution did not produce microbes until a bottle was tipped.”

C.Choice: “Pasteur shone a beam of light into the dark auditorium.”

D.Choice: “That is because I ... have kept it from the germs that float in the air.”

Content: Which sentence 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 states the central idea of Passage 1?

A.Choice: Pasteur disproved the idea of spontaneous generation.

B.Choice: Pasteur disproved the effectiveness of sealed flasks.

C.Choice: Pasteur disproved the existence of dust particles.

D.Choice: Pasteur disproved the need for yeast water.

Content: How does Passage 2 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 illustrate the length of time microbes have been on Earth compared to that of humans and other animals?

A.Choice: by using an analogy of a calendar year to describe Earth's history

B.Choice: by describing the development of life on Earth in chronological order

C.Choice: by breaking down the different kinds of life on Earth into different categories

D.Choice: by showing how many more microbes there are on Earth than there are humans

Content: In Passage 2, what is the effect of comparing the number of microbes to the human population and the number of stars in the Milky Way?

A.Choice: It shows readers how small microbial populations are.

B.Choice: It provides context for how large microbial populations are.

C.Choice: It describes ways to count the total population of microbes.

D.Choice: It illustrates that microbial populations cannot be estimated.

Content: In Passage 2, what text structure does the author 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡𝗟𝗬 use in paragraphs 3–6?

A.Choice: chronological

B.Choice: order of importance

C.Choice: problem and solution

D.Choice: compare and contrast

Content: How is the treatment of the topic of microbes different in Passage 1 and Passage 2?

A.Choice: Passage 1 shows how microbes appear in a laboratory environment; Passage 2 describes how microbes reproduce in the natural environment.

B.Choice: Passage 1 reveals how our knowledge of microbes was limited; Passage 2 suggests how our knowledge of microbes has expanded in recent years.

C.Choice: Passage 1 explains a milestone in scientific understanding of microbes; Passage 2 emphasizes the early existence and astounding number of microbes in the environment.

D.Choice: Passage 1 demonstrates how the scientific community hindered our understanding of microbes; Passage 2 suggests that mathematical formulas can increase our understanding of microbes.

Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 3.
:box:Ventriloquists use the brain's desire to merge what we are seeing with what we are hearing to create an illusion that tricks the brain.
Which detail from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports this claim?

A.Choice: Obstacles in a room can make it difficult to determine where the sound came from.

B.Choice: Ventriloquists focus the attention of the audience to conceal the source of a sound.

C.Choice: Ventriloquists start with a single puppet to engage the audience with its sound.

D.Choice: Sounds travel through the air to stimulate the senses.

Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Which sentence 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 describes how paragraph 4 contributes to the section Tʜᴇ Sᴄɪᴇɴᴄᴇ Bᴇʜɪɴᴅ Vᴇɴᴛʀɪʟᴏǫᴜɪsᴍ?

A.Choice: It describes how science can be used to help determine the best environment for making sound.

B.Choice: It explains the science required to know the amount of space needed for people to hear sound.

C.Choice: It suggests that the science of sound will be better understood with further research.

D.Choice: It shows how the science of sound affects what people perceive.

Content: Which choice provides the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: “Sound travels across the molecules in the air.”

B.Choice: “It is the vibration of these molecules that creates sound.”

C.Choice: “If you hear your name in a crowded room, at first you might not know where the sound came from.”

D.Choice: “The brain relies on the other senses to help us figure out the origin of the sound.”

Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 5.
:box:All of this takes place unconsciously for the listener.
What does the word “unconsciously” tell the reader about people watching a ventriloquist?

A.Choice: They fall asleep after the ventriloquism show begins.

B.Choice: They usually are unaware of the techniques of the ventriloquist.

C.Choice: They are tricked into believing that a puppet is speaking.

D.Choice: They often stop paying attention to the show if it becomes too involved.

Content: Based on the passage, what are 𝗧𝗪𝗢 ways ventriloquists make their puppets seem real? Select 𝗧𝗪𝗢 answers.

A.Choice: by using the same voice for the various puppets used in the show

B.Choice: by having the puppets move and behave in convincing ways

C.Choice: by exaggerating the movements of the puppets' mouths

D.Choice: by looking directly at the puppets when speaking to them

E.Choice: by hiding the puppets after they start to speak

Content: Which choice provides the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 objective summary of the passage?

A.Choice: Ventriloquists use scientific data to create humorous illusions onstage. Scientists have found that certain parts of the brain are able to process both sight and sound at the same time.

B.Choice: Ventriloquism is about balancing art and science in a show. I think all ventriloquists are talented at performing funny shows and can often get away with making statements that are odd.

C.Choice: Ventriloquism works due to the science behind sound. Because of the way people process sound, ventriloquists use a variety of techniques in their art to create convincing illusions.

D.Choice: Ventriloquists rely on scientists to create their illusions. Researchers and artists come together to make shows that are more entertaining than most other types of live performances.

Content: What is the 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡 way the author develops the science and art of ventriloquism in the passage?

A.Choice: by introducing a theory and then supporting it with evidence

B.Choice: by describing events in sequential order and then analyzing them

C.Choice: by presenting subtopics with evidence and explaining how they relate to each other

D.Choice: by explaining an opinion and showing how it was shaped by personal experiences

Content: In Passage 1, which evidence 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 explains the reason the eldest son leaves his home?

A.Choice: “The sultan provided him a fine boat ... and best wishes for a safe and wondrous expedition.”

B.Choice: “For even as a small boy, he craned and stretched his neck—longing to see beyond the next turn ... beyond the bay.”

C.Choice: “He was captaining his own boat so that he could see for himself what lay beyond the distant horizon.”

D.Choice: “The eldest observed that the trees were like nothing he had ever seen.”

Content: In Passage 1, paragraphs 7 and 21 reveal na importantly difference between the brothers 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡𝗟𝗬

A.Choice: by suggesting that the eldest brother will continue on his journey, while Sadaka will return home sooner than planned.

B.Choice: by showing how the eldest brother must decide alone what to do with the seeds, while Sadaka can go to the jinns for advice.

C.Choice: by emphasizing that the eldest brother thinks of the fruit as nourishment too, while Sadaka is more interested in its taste.

D.Choice: by showing how the eldest brother assumes he can use the seeds to benefit himself, while Sadaka wants to learn more about them.

Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
In Passage 1, how does the author create suspense in Sadaka's first meeting with the prince?

A.Choice: The reader knows the prince will follow through with his threat to imprison Sadaka, but Sadaka does not believe him.

B.Choice: The reader knows the man the prince has imprisoned is Sadaka's brother, but Sadaka is not aware of this.

C.Choice: The reader worries that Sadaka will be tricked by the prince, but Sadaka trusts they will become friends.

D.Choice: The reader wonders if the jinns' special soil will work, but Sadaka is certain that it will.

Content: Which choice provides the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: “They gave Sadaka the soil he would need, and Sadaka again set sail.”

B.Choice: “Sadaka met the formidable prince and told him of the fruit.”

C.Choice: “If your story proves false, just like him, you shall be imprisoned.”

D.Choice: “You are fortunate, my friend. However, you have one more test.”

Content: What is the theme in Passage 1?

A.Choice: If you travel too far away from home, bad luck may follow you.

B.Choice: Be wary when placing your trust in things that seem too good to be true.

C.Choice: If you take time to help others, they will likely help you in times of trouble.

D.Choice: Close family members are the only people you can rely on when you need help.

Content: In Passage 2, which lines 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗦𝗧𝗥𝗢𝗡𝗚𝗟𝗬 support that the speaker feels isolated?

A.Choice: “One grain of sand / sliding, slipping / beneath the surface,”

B.Choice: “It took patience and remembrance / and courage / for my eyes to adjust to”

C.Choice: “The officer who gave me advice, whispering / in my ear the safest place to cross.”

D.Choice: “We were all grains of sand, / not hiding from the relentless surf,”

Content: Read lines 50–52 from Passage 2.

:box:but rising, a dune of protons, neutrons, electrons
charged, bound, growing, and living,
fed by the bonds between us.
The effect of using this figurative language near the end of the poem shows that the speaker

A.Choice: feels happy about finally learning how to navigate the city.

B.Choice: has now become more self-confident around people.

C.Choice: finally identifies with the commotion of the city.

D.Choice: now feels deeply connected to other people.

Content: Which evidence from Passage 2 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 shows how the speaker has become like Sadaka from Passage 1?

A.Choice: “My aunts and my mother spoke of sadaqah, / the giving of oneself,”

B.Choice: “only protons, neutrons, electrons, / bound tightly together, / surrounded by crust”

C.Choice: “under the thrashing / of an unfamiliar surf.”

D.Choice: “I give thanks. / For the landlady / who needed my help with her Wi-Fi,”

Content: How should the underlined words in sentence 6 be changed to provide a transition from sentence 5?

A.Choice: In the same way

B.Choice: However

C.Choice: Therefore

D.Choice: In fact

Content: Which is the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 choice to replace the underlined portion of sentence 9?

A.Choice: fidgeting wakes us up and concentration is helped.

B.Choice: fidgeting wakes us up and helps us to concentrate.

C.Choice: concentration is helped when fidgeting wakes us up.

D.Choice: we are woken up by fidgeting which helps us concentrate.

Content: In sentence 10, which is the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 choice to replace the word “grow”?

A.Choice: raise

B.Choice: widen

C.Choice: spread

D.Choice: increase

Content: Which sentence should be removed because it is not well connected to the topic of the paragraph?

A.Choice: sentence 10

B.Choice: sentence 11

C.Choice: sentence 12

D.Choice: sentence 13

Content: How should the underlined words in sentence 14 be changed to maintain the style of the passage?

A.Choice: improves students' grades.

B.Choice: bumps up students' grades.

C.Choice: makes students' grades great.

D.Choice: makes students' grades get better.

Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Which sentence is the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 choice to replace sentence 18 as a concluding statement?

A.Choice: Instead of saying “Sit still!” we should command students to “Stand up!” to satisfy the fitness experts.

B.Choice: Rather than “Sit still!” the better command to promote classroom learning is, almost certainly, “Stand up!”

C.Choice: Asking students to “Stand up!” rather than “Sit still!” will improve teacher satisfaction in our nation's schools.

D.Choice: We should say “Stand up!” rather than “Sit still!” to students so that they get more activity and have less need for gym classes.

Content: Which statement provides the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 support for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Very few elementary schools give their students the amount of physical education recommended by health experts.

B.Choice: Teachers are catching on to the idea of encouraging physical activity in classrooms.

C.Choice: Students who use standing desks are more attentive and engaged.

D.Choice: Time spent in gym classes is frequently short as well.

Content: How should sentence 4 be changed to be written in active voice?

A.Choice: As such, they make up the Pando Clone, which scientists believe is the world's largest living thing.

B.Choice: As such, they are being made up by the Pando Clone, which scientists believe is the world's largest living thing.

C.Choice: As such, the Pando Clone is being made up by them and have been believed by scientists to be the world's largest living thing.

D.Choice: As such, they have been made up by the Pando Clone, which is believed by scientists to be the world's largest living thing.

Content: How should the underlined words in sentence 6 be changed to maintain the formal style of the rest of the article?

A.Choice: NO CHANGE

B.Choice: gigantic

C.Choice: jumbo

D.Choice: whopping

Content: Which word or phrase 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 replaces the underlined word in sentence 7?

A.Choice: exactly

B.Choice: close to

C.Choice: more than

D.Choice: precisely

Content: How should the underlined word in sentence 10 be changed to describe the most precise reasoning?

A.Choice: estimate

B.Choice: suspect

C.Choice: suppose

D.Choice: think

Content: Where should sentence 11 be moved to 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 organize the ideas in the article?

A.Choice: after sentence 6

B.Choice: after sentence 8

C.Choice: after sentence 13

D.Choice: after sentence 14

Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
The writer would like to add another example after sentence 12 to expand on its idea. Which sentence would be the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 to add?

A.Choice: There are too many animals such as deer and elk, which causes problems.

B.Choice: Tourists love to explore this national treasure, with thousands of people visiting every year.

C.Choice: Pando's giant root system enables it to survive floods, landslides, and fires.

D.Choice: Animals such as deer and elk like to eat the tree's new stems as they emerge from the soil.

Content: Which sentence provides the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: “Anyone who tours Utah's Fishlake National Forest is likely to marvel at its beautiful grove of aspen trees.”

B.Choice: “However, the 47,000 trees in this woodlands area are not individual trees.”

C.Choice: “Scientists are worried that Pando is not cloning itself as fast as creatures and other environmental changes are destroying it.”

D.Choice: “Although animals sometimes find their way around the fence, many young stems in the enclosed areas appear to be thriving.”

Content: Now read the writing task and draft a response. As you write, think about what makes writing successful.
problems/NMG8E/media/33a.jpg

:box:You have read three articles about the Carlsbad Caverns National Park. The articles include information about tourism and its effects on the state, the caverns, and the caverns' ecosystem. Having read about tourism at the Carlsbad Caverns National Park, take a position about whether the Carlsbad Caverns should remain open for tourism.

You decide to write an argumentative letter to the editor of your local newspaper in which you present your argument and state your position about whether the Carlsbad Caverns should remain open for tourism. Use details and examples from the articles, along with your own ideas and experience, to support your claim and position.

:ibox:Today you will be writing an argument. When you write an argument, you

• make and support a claim based on factual evidence.
• gather and present reasons for making that claim.
• use specific facts, examples, and details to support and elaborate upon those reasons.

After you have read the passages, and before you begin writing, think about

• what evidence in the passages leads you to make your claim about whether the Carlsbad Caverns National Park should remain open for tourists.
• what you already know and what fact-based evidence you have to support your claim about whether the Carlsbad Caverns should remain open for tourism.
• how you might address evidence that supports a different idea or position.

Now write your response in the space provided.
